Title: Introduction to PHY 131
Description: Professor Hemmick introduces himself and the course, and discusses the different class types for introductory physics.

Title: Teaching a Large Course
Description: The larger the class, the more important questions are asked!

Title: Grade Breakdown
Description: Here, the grade breakdown is explained. Exam dates and times are outdated, so MAKE SURE to check Blackboard for latest exam schedules, and for any recent changes to grade breakdowns.

Title: Testing for Online Students
Description: For exams, online students have the option to take exams in person, or at a testing center off-campus.

Title: Memorize vs. Remembering & Understanding
Description: There is a important distinction between memorizing and understanding a formula, which is why the exams are taken with a non-graphing calculator and no formula sheet.

Title: Recitations & Homework
Description: We go over how recitations and homeworks are given, and some more exam info. Make sure to check Blackboard for due dates and updated information!

Title: More on WebAssign
Description: Professor Hemmick explains how to find your WebAssign homeworks. Note that you'll find your's under your Weekly Tasks in the normal course page (not a recitation section).

Title: A Baffling Balloon Behavior (Lect. 2)
Description: Why does a balloon move forward in a moving car?

Title: More Administrivia
Description: We go over some more administrative information about the online vs. in-person sections, as well as that the online lab is a different course than PHY 131.

Title: Should We Use Significant Digits?
Description: Since many people have used significant digits in the past, we discuss why they aren't as good as they're made out to be.

Title: What We Do Instead of Sig Digs
Description: Instead of using significant digits, we should keep enough digits to keep our answer right, but not too many that it's embarrassing!

Title: Using Units
Description: Ten hours is different from ten minutes. Here, we introduce why units are important, and do some unit conversions.

Title: Identities
Description: We cover the different types of identities which "leave something unchanged."

Title: Conversions - Right or Wrong?
Description: There are many ways to do unit conversions. Are some of these methods wrong?

Title: What is 1D Motion?
Description: Motion in one dimension is introduced as a simple function of time, and a bunch of time derivatives.

Title: The Backwards Brain Bicycle (Lect. 3)
Description: "Smarter Every Day" shows us how our brain can be "rewired" to un-learn how to ride a bike.

Title: Motion in 1 Dimension
Description: A continuation of last lecture's introduction to motion in one dimension.

Title: Motion with Constant Acceleration
Description: This video covers force with constant acceleration, and integrating acceleration to get velocity by using definite integrals.

Title: Deriving the Equations of Motion
Description: Prof. Hemmick works through the derivations of the basic equations of motion which will be used in this course.

Title: The Six Questions of Kinematics
Description: We learn the well-formed "when, where, and how fast?" questions we can ask about motion.

Title: Well-Formed and Ill-Formed Information
Description: In order to solve a kinematics problem, we must describe velocity, time, and acceleration in a way that we can get more information than what was originally given.

Title: The World's Roundest Object (Lect. 4)
Description: Veritasium talks about what defined the kilogram

Title: 1D Equations of Motion
Description: Last class we derived the equations of motion in 1D, and now we briefly review and discuss them.

Title: Reviewing Well-Formed Questions
Description: We review how to create well-formed questions, which was introduced last lecture (when, where, how fast?).

Title: Definition of Success
Description: We cover how to identify "success" in a question and how to identify the process to solving this type of problem.

Title: A Definition of Success Problem
Description: You race your friend to grab the dollar on the floor. How can you define success in order to get there first, with the least effort?

Title: Solving the Definition of Success Problem
Description: Since we've defined what we need to outline a definition of success problem, we walk through the problem step by step.

Title: The Pitfalls of Average Velocity
Description: We explain what average velocity is, and why is may be dangerous to use in physics.

Title: Vectors and a 2D Coordinate System
Description: Prof. Hemmick teaches how to use vectors to describe motion in a 2-dimensional plane.

Title: Review - Kinematics in 1D
Description: We review the equations of motion in 1D

Title: Review - Well-Formed Questions & Info
Description: We review well-formed questions and well-formed information.

Title: Review - Definition of Success
Description: We review what "defining success" problems are.

Title: The Importance of Vectors
Description: We can't describe position on a plane with just one number - we need two! Here's why vectors are important to use.

Title: The "Hat" Direction
Description: The "hat" notation strikes fear into the heart of students. Here's what it is, and why you shouldn't be afraid of it.

Title: Magnitude and Direction
Description: Prof. Hemmick teaches the formula for magnitude of a vector, direction of a vector, and the SohCahToa rules.

Title: Free Fall 1
Description: If it needs to be described with two or more numbers, it is a vector!

Title: Free Fall 2
Description: We X-ify and Y-ify our equations of motion, as we would like to describe our motion of free fall by separating motion in the x direction, and the y direction.

Title: Projectile Motion
Description: A brief introduction to talking about projectile motion, and common TV misconceptions about velocity and acceleration.

Title: Throwing a Basketball
Description: Getting a basketball into the hoop is a definition of success problem. We discuss what parameters mean the basketball went in.

Title: Basketball Equations of Motion
Description: We build our equations of motion from our definition of success values for the basketball, and use the equations "simultaneously."

Title: Slip and Fly Problem
Description: We set up a problem for the slip and fly problem, given a starting velocity and y=mx+b formula for the "landing" hill.

Title: Solving the Slip and Fly
Description: We use what is given and our simultaneous equations to find "success" or "landing" for the slip and fly problem.

Title: Projectile Salmon
Description: We do another definition of success problem to calculate the minimum velocity of a projectile salmon.

Title: The Alfa Romeo HW Problem
Description: The Alpha Romeo has a lot of extraneous information, so we read through the problem to see what information is actually useful to build our equations of motion.

Title: Alfa Romeo Equations of Motion
Description: We use our well-formed information about the position and time of the Alpha Romeo to build our simultaneous equations of motion.

Title: The Average Velocity Riddle
Description: Average velocity is often dangerous to use in physics. Prof. H asks you to solve a riddle about Long Island traffic jams.

Title: History of Newton
Description: Prof. Hemmick gives us some history about Isaac Newton and the backstory and controversy about his famed equations describing motion.

Title: Newton's Laws of Motion
Description: What we have done before is not quite "physics," so what we do now is talk about "cause and effect" physics in terms of Newton's Three Laws of Motion.

Title: Newton's Second Law
Description: We continue Newton's Second Law from last lecture, by examining the sum of the forces on an object equalling its mass and acceleration.

Title: The Importance of Bookkeeping
Description: In order to avoid mistakes when solving force problems, we use free-body diagrams to keep track of all the forces on an object.

Title: Intro to Atwood's Machine
Description: The Atwood's Machine is a great tool to learn about forces...If we make sure we don't fall into typical textbook traps.

Title: Free Body Diagram (M)
Description: To simplify this problem, we draw free body diagrams separately for each object. Here, we draw the free body diagram for M, and orient our coordinate system accordingly.

Title: Writing Force Equations
Description: To solve for acceleration and tension, we write the force equation as ma = sum of the forces, and repeat this process of free body diagram and force equation for the smaller mass.

Title: Inclined Plane Free Body Diagram
Description: We draw the free body diagram for two masses on a pulley, but one on an inclined plane, and decide our coordinate system based off the direction of acceleration.

Title: Contact Forces (Friction)
Description: Prof. Hemmick introduces a new force called friction, which will be applied in our inclined plane problem.

Title: Static Friction
Description: Static friction (F_s) is a variable force which is active as you push or pull an object, and your push and pull force is not large enough to move the object.

Title: Kinetic Friction
Description: Kinetic friction (F_k) is the type of friction which opposes sliding as you are already sliding (opposed to static friction, when the object is standing still). Prof. H also talks about anti-lock brakes.

Title: Inclined Plane with Friction
Description: From last class, we introduce friction into our incline plane free body diagram, as well as do a quick review of how we set up our coordinate system.

Title: Breaking Force Into Components
Description: Because our "5g" force doesn't line up with the coordinate system, we need to break it into components using our basic rules of trigonometry.

Title: Incline Plane Force Equations
Description: With all of our forces aligned to the coordinate system, we can now write the force equations in order to solve for acceleration.

Title: Newton's Third Law
Description: Newton's Third Law is best described as "equal and opposite," and we discuss the difference between Newtonian pairs of equal and opposite forces, and just sheer coincidence.

Title: Equal and Opposite
Description: Prof. Hemmick tests our understanding of equal and opposite, and how to include equal and opposite forces in force diagrams.

Title: Third Law Problem
Description: We lay out an old Newton's Third Law exam problem, with an atwood's pulley, two blocks, and friction between them.

Title: Third Law Problem - Free Body Diagram 1
Description: To solve this equal and opposite force problem, we create a free body diagram for the top block and ensure that the equal and opposite forces and dealt with correctly.

Title: Third Law Problem - Free Body Diagram 2
Description: Continuing our free body analysis, we draw the free body diagram for the bottom block, keeping in mind our normal forces, frictions, and equal and opposite forces.

Title: Third Law Problem - Force Equations
Description: Now that we have our force equations, we can simultaneously solve for normal force and acceleration in our system.

Title: Speed, Velocity & Acceleration
Description: We examine the relationship between velocity and acceleration in a given motion.

Title: Deriving Acceleration -- Direction
Description: We begin our derivation of acceleration in uniform circular motion by deducing the appropriate direction of the acceleration vector.

Title: Deriving Acceleration -- Magnitude
Description: We continue derivation of acceleration in uniform circular motion by solving for its magnitude.

Title: Centrifugal "Force" in Theory
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains why centrifugal "force" is not a force at all, providing analogy to a car at a stop light.

Title: Centrifugal "Force" in Action
Description: Prof. Hemmick talks about circular motion in a carnival ride, and outlines steps to solving problems in uniform circular motion: (1) Draw a FBD, (2) Choose coordinates, and (3) Use Newton's Second Law.

Title: Midterm 1 Info
Description: **NOTE** As these lectures were recorded in the past, disregard test dates and room assignments. These will be announced on Blackboard. Additionally, there may be some different topics on THIS YEAR's exam from what was reviewed in these lectures. Blackboard will reflect what topics will be testing on your upcoming Midterm 1.

Title: What's Covered (OLD)
Description: Prof. Hemmick briefly discusses what is covered on midterm 1 for FALL 2018. Your results may vary. Check Blackboard for what to expect on midterm 1.

Title: Content of Exam
Description: We go over the general structure of the exam, and where to look for good practice problems (hint: Homeworks and Problem Solving (Extra Credit) videos!!)

Title: Exam Procedure
Description: To get started on time, there is important procedure to be followed for these large proctored exams. Bring your writing utensils, your student ID, and a NON-GRAPHING CALCULATOR.

Title: Exam Grading
Description: The exam grading rubric is explained (about 75% for physics, 25% for math, and no double jeopardy except if simultaneous equations).

Title: Remote Exams (Some Online Students)
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains the process of taking exams as an online student who requires to take the test off-campus at a testing center. Additionally, some questions about exam technicalities are fielded.

Title: Banked Curve
Description: Roads with banked curves makes turning a corner safer and easier. We go over why this is so.

Title: Solving the Banked Curve
Description: We draw the free-body diagram of a car turning on a banked curve, and discuss what "centripetal force" really means.

Title: Review of Midterm 1 Info
Description: We go over what we need to know about midterm 1. NOTE that the topics on this midterm may vary, check Blackboard for more info.

Title: Review of Remote Exam Info
Description: Some online students may opt to take the exam remotely at a testing center. This is a review of the information covered last lecture.

Title: Online Review Session
Description: In the past, Prof. Hemmick hosted 8-hour review sessions, which were recorded and placed online. You can find these on Blackboard.

Title: More About Midterm 1
Description: Some students have questions about what will be on the test. Although this year it may be different, Prof. Hemmick's philosophy on testing certain units may be useful for you to know.

Title: Newtonian Gravity
Description: The gravitational force equation is briefly reviewed, along with how to describe this force since it occurs between two masses (little m and big M).

Title: Orbiting Problem
Description: When an object is in orbit, it is always falling! We introduce a circular orbit problem which leads us to one of Kepler's Laws.

Title: Camera Obscura in a Uhaul (Lect. 14)
Description: Physics Girl on Youtube shows the process of making a camera obscura from a pinhole mounted on the back of a Uhaul truck.

Title: Again - Info on Midterm 1
Description: Prof. H briefly covers important info for Midterm 1 i.e. no graphing calculator and the weekend review (recording can be found on Blackboard).

Title: Speeding Up and Slowing Down
Description: We consider the forces which cause us to speed up and slow down, along with the mathematical methods used to describe this motion.

Title: Dot Products
Description: We discuss dot products (scalar products) in order to help us describe motion, by examining the resultant vector of two vectors with the same starting point.

Title: Force over Distance
Description: Using what we've learned about dot products, we now calculate force "dotted" over a distance (work).

Title: Cause and Effect
Description: Looking at our force dotted with distance, we take a look at the cause and effects of these mathematical descriptions of motion.

Title: Improving the Work Formula
Description: In order to improve the work formula, the motion displacements must be infinitesimally small (hint: integrals!)

Title: Work in a Projectile Motion Problem
Description: Prof. Hemmick breaks down a projectile motion problem by explaining the Work done on a calculator if a student were to throw it off a cliff.

Title: Feeling Temperature with a Haptic Glove (Lect. 14)
Description: Destin from Smarter Every Day talks about virtual reality gloves which cause the user to feel temperature and pressure.

Title: Post-Review Session Midterm Info
Description: Review of important information about the upcoming first midterm.

Title: What We've Learned So Far
Description: We briefly go over what was introduced about work in last lecture.

Title: Work Due to Gravity
Description: Prof. H teaches what work due to gravity looks like, by breaking down force over a distance.

Title: Work of a Spring
Description: Using the Hooke's Law formula for force due to a spring, we find the work done by a spring.

Title: Conservative and Non-Conservative Work
Description: Sometimes we say energy is "lost" from a system, and this section we make the distinction between conservative work and non-conservative work.

Title: Work vs. Change in Total Energy
Description: Work (non-conservative) = the change in total energy, and here we explain the "two" ways to describe this law.

Title: Problem - Conservation of Energy at Different Moments
Description: Prof. Hemmick does Work(NC) problem on a moving block, to compare total energy at different moments in time.

Title: Day Before Midterm 1: Info
Description: This video gives pertinent information about previous year's midterm 1, such as the topics covered, where the questions come from, room assignments, grading schema, and information for remote students and testing centers. Has time-specific information about when testing remote testing center form must be filled out by. Refer to Blackboard for THIS semester's specific info.

Title: Starting Banked Curve Problem
Description: To review for the midterm, the students select a banked curve problem to do. We make the distinction between a car moving too slow, and a car moving too fast, and what happens in either case.

Title: Completing the Free-Body Diagram
Description: Tensions, normals, frictions, and gravity are all the forces that we need for all force force problems, even for centripetal motion problems! We also align our coordinate systems in this section and break them into components.

Title: Constructing the Force Equations
Description: Using our components, we build the force equations for the 'too slow' and 'too fast' scenarios.

Title: Atwood's Machine on a Ramp
Description: This is an overview of a two mass atwood's machine on a ramp. This problem uses kinetic friction, tension, and some other forces, and are summarized on a free-body diagram. Prof. Hemmick solves for the tension, normal force, and acceleration.

Title: Basics of Energy Review
Description: We recall our definition of energy and basic properties, starting from our definition of work and evaluating its relationship to kinetic and potential energy.

Title: A Practice Problem -- Setup
Description: We set up a practice problem to solve involving newly learned concepts in total energy, kinetic energy, potential energy, and non-conservative forces.

Title: A Practice Problem -- Solving for v_2
Description: We begin solving our practice problem by finding v_2.

Title: A Practice Problem -- Choosing Reference Energy
Description: Oftentimes in energy problems, we can compare energies at moments (1) and (2), or (1) and (3). Prof. Hemmick outlines some guidelines on which comparison to choose.

Title: A Practice Problem -- Solving for v_3
Description: We continue solving our practice problem by finding v_3.

Title: A Practice Problem -- Solving for d
Description: We finish solving our practice problem by figuring out work due to friction and solving for d.

Title: Energy Problems in General
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains how to use the above steps to solve general energy problems, and what creates difficulties in them.

Title: Review of Work
Description: We review the principles of work and its relation to energy.

Title: An Application of Work
Description: Prof. Hemmick gives a familiar example where the relationship between work and energy makes a problem easier to solve.

Title: Defining Impulse
Description: Multiplying force by distance got us a useful quantity in work. We try this strategy again, multiplying force by time to get impulse.

Title: Defining Systems
Description: Work became useful when we could use it to ignore certain quantities. We see how Newton's Third Law allows us to consider only impulse external to a system.

Title: Impulse and Momentum
Description: Using our deduction of a system, we write impulse in a more useful way by considering its relationship to momentum.

Title: Ideal Collisions
Description: We apply our new knowledge of impulse to study ideal collisions.

Title: An Example of Collision -- Statement
Description: Prof. Hemmick shares an anecdote to motivate the study of collisions.

Title: An Example of Collision -- Calculation
Description: We make a calculation for the mentioned example using the relationship between impulse and momentum.

Title: Regrading Policy
Description: Prof. Hemmick shares information on policy regarding grading errors. Note that this is from a past semester; check Blackboard for any discrepancies.

Title: Revisiting the Car Problem
Description: We revisit the car problem from last class, adding in considerations of friction.

Title: Time and Ideal Collisions
Description: In reaction to answers to a question, Prof. Hemmick explains why time has to approach zero in an idealized collision.

Title: Using Momentum and Energy
Description: We finish the car problem by adding considerations of both energy and momentum to calculate the velocities of each car.

Title: Questions and Answers
Description: Prof. Hemmick answers some questions regarding the preceding calculation.

Title: Deciding When to Use What
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains how to decide when to use energy and momentum in a problem.

Title: Deriving an Equation for Elastic Collisions
Description: We derive an equation for simplifying 1D elastic collisions.

Title: Review of Collisions
Description: We review the basic concept of analyzing collisions from last class: look at quantities directly before and directly after collision.

Title: Review of Elastic Collisions
Description: We further review the equation derived last class for the specific example of 1-dimensional elastic collisions.

Title: Breaking Down Equations
Description: No we physically interpret the equation for 1D elastic collisions.

Title: A Practical Consideration
Description: From our analysis, we need two equations to solve problems, but have three choices. Prof. Hemmick walks through practical considerations on which equations to use.

Title: A New Type of Problem
Description: So far we've learned about mechanics when a system is moving in some translational motion; what about the case where an object is in rotation?

Title: Units in Rotational Problems
Description: Angular quantities are defined completely analogously to translational quantities, but oftentimes people find them more difficult. Prof. Hemmick explains the main difference in these types of problems.

Title: Constant Alpha
Description: Before, we saw constant acceleration led to simplifications in equations of motion; constant angular acceleration is no different.

Title: Recap of Rotational Kinematics
Description: We quickly review what we learned from last class about rotational kinematics. We also think about what makes rotational problems harder.

Title: Next Thing to do
Description: Previously, we've learned about kinematics, force, energy, and momentum. Prof. Hemmick explains why we investigate energy next.

Title: The Problem
Description: There's a small twist in figuring out kinetic energy: the translational velocity of a point is dependent on its radius from the axis of rotation. However, the angular velocity is the same at all points.

Title: Kinetic Energy Formula
Description: We take our observations into consideration and derive a formula for kinetic energy.

Title: Moment of Inertia
Description: In our formula for kinetic energy, we notice the formula actually depends on m_i r_i instead of just m_i. This leads us to defining the moment of inertia, discussing how it gets its name.

Title: General Difficulties
Description: We've now introduced a new difficulty in studying rotational problems. We recap what makes these problems more difficult.

Title: Useful Moments
Description: For now, there are a few shapes which we'll memorize the moment of inertia for. Prof. Hemmick introduces these.

Title: Pinewood Derby
Description: As a motivating example, Prof. Hemmick talks about a key to Pinewood Derby competitions.

Title: Importance of Moments
Description: In Pinewood Derby competitions, solid wheels is a key. We make a quick calculation to show how this small difference in moment of inertia makes such a big difference.

Title: Recap of Energy
Description: We recap what we covered last class regarding rotational problems.

Title: Moments we Know
Description: We already know a few moments of inertia by memorization, as well as how to calculate point mass objects.

Title: Continuous Mass Distribution
Description: We set up the integral for I under continuous mass distribution.

Title: Parallel Axis Theorem
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains the parallel axis theorem, another way to find I.

Title: Composite Object
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains the final of the five ways to find I.

Title: What is Integration
Description: We take a critical view of what integration fundamentally is.

Title: Calculating Examples
Description: We recover the example of the moment of inertia of a rod from the end and center using the integral formula. A problem on the second midterm will be a similar example.

Title: Recap of I
Description: We recap what we've learned about the moment of inertia, including the five ways to find it.

Title: Introduction to Torque
Description: Prof. Hemmick shows off a feat of strength to motivate the study of torque.

Title: Equation for Torque --Magnitude
Description: Prof. Hemmick derives the equation for magnitude of torque.

Title: Equation for Torque -- Direction
Description: Prof. Hemmick discusses the mathematical formulation of direction for torque, as well as the convention we'll use in this class.

Title: Practicing with Yoyos -- FBD
Description: Using our new knowledge of torque, we think about a yoyo as our first example problem. In this video, we set up the free body diagrams.

Title: Practicing with Yoyos -- Equations
Description: After setting up free body diagrams, we set up equations for the problem.

Title: In Motion and Stationary
Description: A lot of textbooks split the cases where we're stationary and moving in the sum of torques equation, but they're really the same thing!

Title: Recap of Torque
Description: We recap what we learned about torque last lecture.

Title: Diving Board -- Intro
Description: We set up a classic problem in studying torque by looking at the torques of someone on a diving board. In this video we discuss some underlying principles in this problem.

Title: Diving Board -- Solving
Description: Using the underying principles we just discussed, we set up a free-body diagram and solve the problem.

Title: Ladder Problem -- FBD
Description: Another classical problem in studying torque is the torques on a ladder. In this video we set up the free-body diagram for such a problem.

Title: Ladder Problem -- Solving
Description: We use the setup from the last video to solve the ladder problem.

Title: Intro to Angular Momentum
Description: The last translational quantity we have yet to convert to an angular case is momentum. The story is much the same, we'll just end up replacing mass with the moment of inertia!

Title: Plate Spinning
Description: We solve a basic example problem by thinking about a performer spinning a plate, and what would happen if mass got added at some point.

Title: Changing I
Description: Prof. Hemmick demonstrates what happens to angular velocity when we change the moment of inertia thanks to conservation of angular momentum.

Title: Midterm 2 Topics (OLD)
Description: Prof. Hemmick goes over Midterm 2 Topics. NOTE: This is a recording from a prior semester, information may vary. Be sure to check Blackboard to verify correct information!

Title: Remote Exams (Some Online Students)
Description: Some online students may opt to take the exam remotely at a testing center. This is a review of the information covered last lecture.

Title: Review Sessions
Description: In the past, Prof. Hemmick hosted 8-hour review sessions, which were recorded and placed online. You can find these on Blackboard.

Title: More Remarks on MT2
Description: Prof. Hemmick makes some final remarks and fields a few questions regarding midterm 2. Once again, this is from a prior semester, so be sure to check Blackboard for the newest information.

Title: One Final Problem
Description: In the interest of time, we won't do any more problems on angular momentum in class. However, Prof. Hemmick (highly) recommends looking at a particular extra credit video dealing with angular momentum.

Title: Continuum vs Discrete
Description: So far, we've delt with discrete mechanics, i.e. mechanics of some number of objects. We compare this situation to that of continuum mechanics, where quantities are properties of a continuous "stream."

Title: Bernoulli's Equation
Description: Using our knowledge of energy and discussion of continuum mechanics, we derive Bernoulli's equation, an equation relating pressures, densities, and velocities.

Title: Pascal's Law
Description: Oftentimes in intro physics textbooks, discussions of fluids will begin with Pascal's Law. Prof. Hemmick discusses that this is simply a triviality of Bernoulli's equation.

Title: Digesting Bernoulli's Equation
Description: We've shown Bernoulli's equation relates pressure and velocity. We think physically about what this actually means in a number of examples.

Title: Flex Seal Demo
Description: Later this lecture we'll explore Archimedes' Principle the the bouyant force. Here's a cool boat floating.

Title: Midterm 2 Info Again (OLD)
Description: Prof. Hemmick gives a rapid-fire review of information regarding midterm 2 from last class. NOTE: This was recorded in a prior semester, so information may be different. Be sure to check Blackboard for the most accurate information regarding this semester's exam.

Title: Recap of Bernoulli's Equation
Description: We review Bernoulli's equation from last lecture, and some applications between how it relates velocity and pressure.

Title: Spinning Balls
Description: As it turns out, a lot of sports are interesting precisely because of Bernoulli's principle -- it's what allows balls to curve! We examine the relationship between spin on a ball and its trajectory, sometimes called the "Magnus effect."

Title: More Examples
Description: We consider a few more applications of Bernoulli's equation. For example, consider blowing air through two pieces of paper: what happens to the distance between them?

Title: Continuity Equations
Description: There's one thing missing from Bernoulli's equation: conservation of mass. We add it here to derive the continuity equations.

Title: Archimedes' Principle
Description: Archimides' is said to have figured out the relationship between the bouyant force on an object and the water it displaces over 2,000 years ago. We derive his result using our more modern tools.

Title: Roth Regatta
Description: An example application of Archimedes' principle is to the bouyant force of a boat. Prof. Hemmick shares stories of Roth Regatta, and a common mistake while calculating the bouyant force using Archimedes' principle.

Title: Midterm 2 Info Once Again (OLD)
Description: Prof. Hemmick gives a rapid-fire review of information regarding midterm 2 from last class. NOTE: This was recorded in a prior semester, so information may be different. Be sure to check Blackboard for the most accurate information regarding this semester's exam.

Title: Intro to SHM
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains a road-map for the way we'll learn simple harmonic motion, which is when we have some force such that F = -kx.

Title: Equation for SHM -- DEs
Description: In order to find a general solution to the equations of simple harmonic motion, we can't avoid calculus. More specifically, we'll require a brief excursion into differential equations.

Title: Equation for SHM -- Solving
Description: After our discussion of differential equations, we solve for the general solution in simple harmonic motion, sinusoidal functions.

Title: Relating Variables
Description: Now that we have an expression for x, v, and a, we can figure out the relationships between them.

Title: General Cases
Description: We make some general observations about SHM, and get a look forward into some cases where SHM appears.

Title: More Midterm 2 Info (OLD)
Description: Prof. Hemmick gives a rapid-fire review of information regarding midterm 2 from last class. NOTE: This was recorded in a prior semester, so information may be different. Be sure to check Blackboard for the most accurate information regarding this semester's exam.

Title: Recap of SHM -- Equations and Relations
Description: We recall from last lectures the equations governing simple harmonic motion, and the relations between variables.

Title: Recap of SHM -- What is omega?
Description: We review the value of omega in various SHM problems, as well as its relation to important variables like the maximums of x, v, and a.

Title: A Practice Problem
Description: Prof. Hemmick walks us through a practice problem combining much of the information we've just learned about simple harmonic motion.

Title: Physical Pendulum
Description: The past few lectures, we've learned about torque and simple harmonic motion. After making a simple approximation, we can combine these concepts to study something called a physical pendulum.

Title: Day Before Midterm 2 Info
Description: Prof. Hemmick briefly reviews pertinent information for midterm 2. The rules are the same as for midterm 1. However, make sure to check Blackboard for updated information for THIS year's midterm 2.

Title: Bernoulli Problem Review
Description: Prof. Hemmick reviews a Bernoulli problem which requires the continuity equation. We set up the problem and identify our two locations of interest.

Title: Gauge Pressure vs. Absolute Pressure
Description: We have the option to use gauge pressure or absolute pressure.  The difference between them is similar to the difference between using Celsius and Kelvin.

Title: Applying the Continuity Equation
Description: We now build our equation in order to solve for the velocities and pressures applied by the pump, as well as solve for how many kilograms per second.

Title: Archimedes Problem Review
Description: We examine a hauling boat problem in two scenarios: before it is loaded, and after it is loaded.

Title: Archimedes Problem Part B
Description: We draw the free body diagram of the boat that is now loaded with coal, and examine when it would begin to sink.

Title: Torque Problem with Acceleration
Description: Prof. Hemmick does a torque with acceleration problem which is a little bit harder than what would be found on an exam.

Title: How to Make a Square Vortex Ring (Lect. 30)
What We've Learned (Before the Midterm)
Description: We review the difference between continuum mechanics and discrete mechanics (the restoring forces). Prof. H also covers what we learned about simple harmonic motion and restoring forces.

Title: Continuum Mechanics with Restoring Force
Description: Prof. H discusses the continuum of the air, and the restoring forces which cause any perturbations in air pressure to be adjusted (like  our vocal cords compressing air and making noise).

Title: Waves on a String
Description: We can describe a wave well by examining a plucked string under tension, and we look at why the second derivative is important for describing a wave.

Title: Slope of a Plucked String
Description: Each different part of a plucked string moves differently. Prof. H draws a free body diagram of a plucked string.

Title: Getting Rid of M
Description: We do not want to have mass in a continuum mechanics problem. Thus, we must replace it!

Title: Solving the Wave Equation
Description: Since we found the wave equation, we want to know what the solution is.

Title: What We've Learned - SHM
Description: Last class, we learned about how the second derivative is important in describing a wave in simple harmonic motion, as well as how this unit applied to continuum mechanics.

Title: Units of SHM
Description: The wave equation has derivatives with respect to x and with respect to t. Prof. H teaches us how to handle these, and how to make their units work so that LHS = RHS.

Title: The Solution of the Wave Equation
Description: The solution of the wave equation can be any function - as long as it moves with the right velocity!

Title: Velocity of Waves
Description: The velocity of a wave is a very important value which we use for further calculations (like interference!). We go over the different wave velocities for a string, air, compression of a gas, etc.

Title: The Wave Equation as a Sine Function
Description: Given a wave with a wavelength, we are able to construct a function of position and time in order to describe our wave.

Title: Doppler Effect
Description: We have all experienced the Doppler Effect at one point or another. The frequency we hear can be altered depending on if the sound source is moving towards us, or away from us.

Title: Intensity of a Wave
Description: Waves transport energy, and that energy can be spread out over a large area. Prof. Hemmick talks about how the energy spreads in a sphere from a source.

Title: The Decibel
Description: The decibel has an interesting logarithmic history. Prof. Hemmick explains how the unit of sound intensity got its name.

Title: Waves in Finite Media
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains what happens when we send waves through finite media, and shows how standing waves are created.

Title: Waves at a Boundary
Description: Waves look differently inside a container depending on what the boundaries look like. Prof. Hemmick describes what a wave and its frequency look like at closed-closed, open-open, and closed-open boundaries.

Title: Examples of Waves at a Boundary
Description: There are lots of real-world examples of different boundaries, and Prof. H provides lots of musical instruments with closed boundaries, open boundaries, and open-closed boundaries.

Title: What We Learned Last Class - Waves
Description: Prof. H reviews what we went over about waves, the wave equation, velocity, and what happens at different wave boundaries.

Title: A Higher Fundamental Mode
Description: A student shows how to play an instrument in a higher fundamental mode by placing (not pressing) his finger on the center of the string, forcing that location to have a node.

Title: Thicker and Thinner Strings
Description: The mass per unit length (mu) is important for determining the pitch of an instrument's strings, as demonstrated in this section.

Title: Frets and a Musical Performance
Description: A fundamental difference between a guitar and viola/violin/cello/bass is that the former has frets to help set the string length. We also get a musical demonstration from our volunteers!

Title: Wind Instruments
Description: Wind instruments vary in the medium they vibrate, or create waves in; string instruments use their strings, and wind instruments use air. Prof. H demonstrates waves in a wind instrument, the flute.

Title: Clarinet, Oboe, and Saxophone
Description: A flute has open-open boundaries, but a clarinet, oboe, saxophone have a different type of boundary. That means changing the pitch of the instrument is a little bit different, as Prof. H demonstrates.

Title: Equation of State
Description: Particles in the air push against the wall and apply pressure. However, it's difficult to describe this on a microscopic scale, so we aim to describe this on a macroscopic scale with the equation of state (ideal gas law).

Title: PV=nkT
Description: In order to describe the temperature, volume, number of particles, and pressure of an ideal gas, we use the ideal gas law. However, we need to use a correction factor "R" or "k" to get our answer in the correct units

Title: Units for Ideal Gas
Description: Prof. Hemmick briefly covers the logic behind some of the units used in the ideal gas law.

Title: Modeling the Ideal Gas
Description: We want to try to get an equation which looks like PV=nkT, so we model a system of a bunch of gas molecules hitting a wall.

Title: Kinetic Theory
Description: We have described the temperature of a molecule with respect to its kinetic energy. In this section we delve into the kinetic theory of gases.

Title: Shapes of Electron Clouds
Description: Shapes of electron "orbits," better described as "clouds" can vary depending on the amount of valence electrons in an atom. We discuss the ramifications of this on our kinetic theory of gases.

Title: Interlude About Wave Functions
Description: Prof. Hemmick talks a little bit about the wave function about how to find the probability density (not required material, but similar to what we will discuss!)

Title: Ideal Gas Law Review
Description: We quickly go over what we've covered last class about the Ideal Gas Law.

Title: Root Mean Square
Description: We want to express the velocity of our particles as an average, but some of them are negative and others are positive, which gives us a useless mean of zero! Instead, we use the root-mean-squared.

Title: Monatomic, Diatomic, and Polyatomic Gases
Description: From last class, we learned about the different contributors to kinetic energy. Here, Prof. Hemmick goes over translational, rotational, and vibrational kinetic energies for different types of gases.

Title: Heat - The Gift of Energy
Description: Prof. H explains the heat capacity of an ideal gas with respect to the type of particle we have: monatomic, diatomic, or polyatomic.

Title: Why Aliens Won't Respect Our Science
Description: Our typically-used "mCAT" formula is fundamentally unintuitive, so much that if aliens land on our planet they will ask "what were you thinking?"

Title: The Phases of Matter
Description: Our Q=mc Delta T formula can be used for materials that are within 1 phase. We go over how that applies to our systems, as well as cover what latent heat is.

Title: Review of Last Class
Description: We briefly discuss what we covered last class for our Q=mCAT formula, as well as using latent heat to pass between phases.

Title: Solving an Ice Problem
Description: Prof. H proposes a question about tossing ice cubes with a temperature BELOW zero into a drink. Remember: equilibrium does not always mean that all the ice melts!

Title: Guessing our System
Description: There are four different scenarios which might happen when we throw ice into the water (for example, all the water might become ice!). Prof. H goes over these different possibilities and writes Q = 0 equations for them.

Title: How to Know Our Guess is Right
Description: Now, we have our four scenarios of putting ice into a liquid. In order to know which of our scenarios is correct, we need to recognize if our answer is correct, or completely nonsense!

Title: Exploding Buckets
Description: Prof. Hemmick did some crazy things as a kid. Here, he talks about creating a bucket-rocket from a cherry bomb.

Title: Using PV=nRT
Description: We take a closer look at the ideal gas law and at four possible situations: constant pressure (isobaric), constant volume (isochoric), constant temperature (isothermal), and Q=0 (adiabatic).

Title: Internal Energy, Heat, and Work
Description: We very frequently misuse the term "heat," and Prof. Hemmick begins his discussion about how to use them correctly.

Title: Work of a Gas
Description: Force isn't very useful when talking about a gas, so we alter our work formula. Prof. H also reviews our constant pressure, temperature, volume, and Q=0 scenarios.

Title: Delta U (Internal Energy)
Description: We can write our change in internal energy as a function of the transfer of energy from one thing to another (Q) and work done by the gas (W).

Title: Heat and Internal Energy
Description: Prof. H dispels a common misunderstanding that temperature is related to heat, while temperature actually is related to internal energy U.

Title: More About Misconceptions
Description: Prof. H fields some questions about the Delta U = Q - W formula, and stresses that Q is NOT T!

Title: The Table
Description: We create a table of expressions for work, heat transfer, and internal energy given isoP, isoT, isoV, and adiabatic processes.

Title: More of the Table
Description: Prof. Hemmick fields some questions about the table and continues to fill it out. We also examine the C_p and gamma variables more closely.

Title: Information About the Final
Description: Prof. Hemmick outlines what the final looked like in 2018. Make sure to check Blackboard for what THIS semester's final will look like. Many of the review recordings can be found on Blackboard.

Title: Why Textbooks are Bad at Thermo
Description: Many textbooks struggle to teach thermodynamics to students. Prof. Hemmick explains why, and how he plans to fix it.

Title: Engine - Piston in Hot and Cold
Description: Prof. Hemmick shows an engine made of a cylinder and piston, being placed in a hot area and a cold area, and the resulting work and heat transfer.

Title: Refrigerator - Piston in Hot and Cold
Description: Prof. Hemmick explains how the gas inside the cooling tubes of a refrigerator are expanded and compressed in order to cool the inside of the refrigerator.

Title: Fridge and Heat Pump
Description: The engine is intended to do work for us, but fridges and heat pumps we need to put work into to do what we want them to. We add the fridge and heat pump (basically a reverse fridge) to our table.

Title: What You Get vs. What You Paid For
Description: We compare what we get out of these devices to what we paid for them to do it.

Title: P-V Diagrams
Description: We draw a Pressure vs. Volume diagrams for the engine, heat pump and refrigerator, and examine what happens during each different kind of process.

Title: Heat Engine
Description: Prof. H outlines a heat engine problem on a P-V graph.

Title: Final Exam Details
Description: Prof. H describes the format of the upcoming final exam, along with the information students are expected to know and be prepared to answer on come exam day. Check Blackboard for THIS semesters updated information.

Title: General Thermodynamic Cycles
Description: Prof. H distinguishes between the Engine, Fridge, and Heat Pump, giving a physical picture for how each of the three cycles accomplishes different goals. We additionally discuss important quantities for each of these cycles, namely the coefficient of performance and efficiency.

Title: A Cycle Example: Part A) State Table
Description: Prof. H steps through a 3 process thermodynamic cycle, walking the class through how to properly combine given information to calculate unknown state variables such as P, V, and T.

Title: A Cycle Example: Part B) Process Table
Description: We shift our gaze beyond analyzing the individual states on a P-V diagram to studying the processes which take us from one state to the next. Prof. H outlines general formulas applicable for Iso P, Iso T, Iso V, and Adiabatic Processes, as well as applies these formulas to the problem.

Title: A Cycle Example: Part C) Full Cycle Analysis
Description: Combining the information garnered from each of the three processes, Professor Hemmick elaborates on the important Total quantities for the full cycle. Additionally, he highlights some of the mistakes commonly made on exams when it comes to cycle problems.

Title: A Cycle Example: Part D) Final Evaluation
Description: Professor Hemmick discusses the core differences between Heat Pump and Fridges when it comes to calculate Q_H and Q_C. The meanings of these two independent variables are discussed, and are utilized to calculate the overall efficiency of the example engine.

Title: Class Questions
Description: Professor Hemmick fields questions about heat pumps, fridges, and the example problem from the class.

Title: What about Gamma
Description: Hemmick speaks about how gamma, a variable which changes depending on the type of gas used in the thermodynamic cycle, ties into the previously described equations. The variable winds up rearing its head during the description of the adiabatic process.

Title: Adiabatic Process
Description: In order to prepare for the final, we outline a heat pump problem with an adiabatic process.

Title: Writing the State Table
Description: In order to complete the analysis of this heat pump, we write the state table from our givens to describe P, V, and T at points a, b, and c.

Title: Using the Adiabat Formulas
Description: Prof. H describes in detail specifically where, in our state table, to apply the adiabatic formulas.

Title: Filling Out the Process Table
Description: Using the information amassed from the state table, we can fill out the process table for this heat pump (W, Q, and Delta U). Prof. H goes over the sanity checks at the end of the table to see if our results make sense.

Title: Sanity Checks and Coefficient of Performance
Description: Prof. H goes over the sanity checks at the end of the table to see if our results make sense. Additionally, he calculates the coefficient of performance for this heat pump and explains what to expect out of this value for engines and refrigerators, too.

Title: Last Bit of PHY 131
Description: Prof. H talks about final room assignments and wraps up PHY 131. Make sure to check Blackboard for the updated information regarding THIS semester's final exam. GOOD LUCK!!
